articles.headline: Russian Ambassador to Turkey Is Assassinated in Ankara
articles.snippet: The shooting at an art exhibit, said to be carried out by a 22-year-old police officer, forced Turkey and Russia to confront a new crisis tied directly to the Syrian conflict.
articles.abstract: The shooting at an art exhibit, said to be carried out by a 22-year-old police officer, forced Turkey and Russia to confront a new crisis tied directly to the Syrian conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Russia’s ambassador to Turkey was assassinated at an Ankara art exhibit on Monday evening by a lone Turkish gunman shouting “God is great!” and “don’t forget Aleppo, don’t forget Syria!” in what the leaders of Turkey and Russia called a provocative terrorist attack.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Berlin Crash Is Suspected to Be a Terror Attack, Police Say
articles.snippet: Police said the truck jumped the sidewalk and drove into crowds at a holiday market, killing 12 and injuring dozens. The suspected driver was arrested.
articles.abstract: Police said the truck jumped the sidewalk and drove into crowds at a holiday market, killing 12 and injuring dozens. The suspected driver was arrested.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The Berlin police said early Tuesday that the killing of at least 12 people and the wounding of dozens more when a truck plowed through a Christmas market on Monday night was “a suspected terrorist attack.”
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy and Alison Smale

articles.headline: Study Tied to Food Industry Tries to Discredit Sugar Guidelines
articles.snippet: Critics say the review, a scathing attack on recommendations to eat less sugar, is the latest in a series of efforts by the food industry to shape global nutrition advice.
articles.abstract: Critics say the review, a scathing attack on recommendations to eat less sugar, is the latest in a series of efforts by the food industry to shape global nutrition advice.
articles.lead_paragraph: A prominent medical journal on Monday published a scathing attack on global health advice to eat less sugar. Warnings to cut sugar, the study argued, are based on weak evidence and cannot be trusted.

articles.headline: Rail Crossing Warnings Are Sought for Mapping Apps
articles.snippet: The National Transportation Safety Board asked tech companies to add the locations of grade crossings into digital maps and to provide alerts for drivers.
articles.abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board asked tech companies to add the locations of grade crossings into digital maps and to provide alerts for drivers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Following directions from Google Maps on a smartphone last year, Jose Alejandro Sanchez-Ramirez turned a Ford truck, hauling a trailer, where he thought the app was telling him to go. But he ended up stuck on the railroad tracks at a poorly marked California crossing.

articles.headline: Electoral College Settles Donald Trump’s Victory, but Little Else
articles.snippet: Electors across the country faced protests, reflecting a vast divide that carried over from a tumultuous race and that the new president will be facing.
articles.abstract: Electors across the country faced protests, reflecting a vast divide that carried over from a tumultuous race and that the new president will be facing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Florida, protesters swarmed the Capitol rotunda, one hoisting a “Trump Is Too Rusky” sign featuring a hammer and sickle. In Wisconsin’s statehouse, a heckler shouted, “We’re all going to go to war and die thanks to you,” during the formal meeting of the Electoral College.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Michael Wines

articles.headline: A New Fund Seeks Both Financial and Social Returns
articles.snippet: William E. McGlashan Jr., a partner at the private equity firm TPG, is developing Rise, a $2 billion social impact fund with a number of well-known philanthropists.
articles.abstract: William E. McGlashan Jr., a partner at the private equity firm TPG, is developing Rise, a $2 billion social impact fund with a number of well-known philanthropists.
articles.lead_paragraph: “There is a lazy mindedness that we afford the do-gooders.”

articles.headline: Germany Releases Berlin Attack Suspect as ISIS Claims Involvement
articles.snippet: German officials, citing a lack of evidence, freed their initial suspect in the assault that killed 12, and continued to search for an attacker that the militant group said had acted on its behalf.
articles.abstract: German officials, citing a lack of evidence, freed their initial suspect in the assault that killed 12, and continued to search for an attacker that the militant group said had acted on its behalf.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For a Germany that likes to see itself as meticulous, the slip-up was startling: Hours after the authorities said they had grabbed a suspect in the deadly truck rampage at a Christmas market in Berlin, they acknowledged they may have detained the wrong man and began a desperate search for the actual driver.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy and Alison Smale

articles.headline: Russian Cyberforgers Steal Millions a Day With Fake Sites
articles.snippet: A criminal ring is diverting as much as $5 million in advertising revenue a day in a scheme to show video ads to phantom internet users.
articles.abstract: A criminal ring is diverting as much as $5 million in advertising revenue a day in a scheme to show video ads to phantom internet users.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a twist on the peddling of fake news to real people, researchers say a Russian cyberforgery ring has created more than half a million fake internet users and 250,000 fake websites to trick advertisers into collectively paying as much as $5 million a day for video ads that are never watched.

articles.headline: To Problems With China’s Financial System, Add the Bond Market
articles.snippet: More than a year after the country’s stock market crashed, the $9 trillion bond market, a crucial part of efforts to overhaul the economy, is suffering.
articles.abstract: More than a year after the country’s stock market crashed, the $9 trillion bond market, a crucial part of efforts to overhaul the economy, is suffering.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Chinese officials cheered on the country’s stock market when it reached heady new highs, offering hope that it could become a new source of money to fix China’s economic problems. Then, last year, the market crashed.
